normalised: What exactly is a good rental yield in India right now? I keep hearing different things!

unnormalised: **What exactly *is* a good rental yield in India right now? I keep hearing different things!**

normalised: Basically, rental yield is the annual rental income you get from a property divided by its current market value, expressed as a percentage. So, if you buy a flat in Bandra for rupee one point five crore and rent it out for rupee forty thousand per month, your gross rental yield is roughly forty thousand multiplied by twelve divided by one crore fifty lakh equals three point two percent.

normalised: Generally, anything above four percent is considered pretty good in cities like Mumbai or Bangalore right now. However, keep in mind that this is a gross yield. You also need to factor in property taxes, maintenance (think leaky taps and annual Diwali cleaning!), and periods when the property is vacant.

normalised: Areas like Noida or smaller Tier-two cities might offer slightly higher yields, maybe closer to five to six percent, because property prices are relatively lower compared to rentals.

normalised: Think of it like this: getting a six percent yield is like winning a small Onam bumper lottery every year! So do your research! Speak to property consultants. Do not just blindly trust that broker uncleji at the corner shop. It depends heavily on location, property type (two B H K versus independent house), and current market conditions. Good luck!
